awd_titl_txt: Large-Scale Fork-Join Networks with Synchronization Constraints
awd_abstract_narration:
Fork-join networks with synchronization constraints can be widely used to model patient flows in hospitals (e.g., emergency department treatment and patient discharge process) and data centers (e.g., parallelized Web search), among many other applications.  In such networks, jobs are forked into parallel tasks to be served at service stations with parallel servers, and tasks are then joined for job completion or further processing provided that certain synchronization constraints are satisfied, for example, only completed tasks from the same job can be joined (non-exchangeable).  However, very little is known about the performance, reliability and control of these networks, and existing methods in stochastic networks cannot be applied to study them. This award supports development of new methodology to better understand important performance measures (e.g., congestions and response times) of fork-join networks with non-exchangeable synchronization constraints, to design reliable fork-join networks with synchronization constraints operating in dynamic random environments, and to manage them in a cost-effective way. The research findings will have a broad impact on the society by improving the efficiency and quality of services in healthcare and data centers. The research will result in young STEM-trained graduates and underrepresented groups with new mathematical tools that help understand and improve the delivered services. 

The main mathematical challenge to study fork-join networks of multi-server service stations with non-exchangeable synchronization lies in the resequencing of arrival orders after service completion at each station due to randomness of service times. Unlike classical queueing networks, delay for synchronization is a key performance measure affecting system congestion, while resequencing is its determining factor. No analytical methods and results are known for such networks. This research will develop a new framework to solve the resequencing problem in fork-join networks, and thus, result in effective approximations for the synchronization dynamics as well as the service dynamics. The approach will use multi-parameter stochastic processes to study the service, queueing and synchronization dynamics, including sequential empirical processes driven by random vectors and their limits, and two-parameter processes tracking elapsed and residual service and wait times. Coordination and information sharing among parallel tasks of each job during their services will be exploited to develop optimal control policies for fork-join networks with synchronization constraints in order to minimize delay for synchronization as well as delay for service. Preventive strategies will be provided on the design and management of reliable fork-join networks with synchronization constraints operating in dynamic random environments.

por.por_cntn:
The objective of this research is to develop new methods for the analysis and design of large-scale fork-join networks with synchronization constraints. In the fork-join network systems, jobs are forked into parallel tasks to be served at service stations with many parallel servers, and tasks can only be synchronized for job completion or further processing when all the parallel tasks of the same job are completed, which is called  non-exchangeable synchronization (NES). Fork-join networks with NES constraints can be used to model patient flows in hospitals (e.g., emergency department treatment and patient discharge process) and data centers (e.g., parallelized Web search), among many other applications. The proposed research will provide asymptotic approximations for performance measures of fork-join networks with NES constraints, e.g., congestions and response times,  when the demand is high and each service station has many parallel servers, and  when the system is operating in a random environment that may affect the arrival, service and/or synchronization processes.  Important insights will be provided to the understanding and management of a large class of important  fork-join networks with NES constraints that have been difficult to analyze.

Fork-join networks of multi-server service stations with non-exchangeable synchronization cannot be analyzed with conventional approaches to the study of stochastic networks, because of resequencing of arrival orders. Unlike classical queueing networks, delay for synchronization is a determining factor affecting system congestion. No analytical results are known for such networks.(1) We have developed Gaussian random fields methods, particularly, multiparameter sequential empirical processes, and established functional limit theorems for two-parameter stochastic processes describing the service, queueing and synchronization dynamics when each service station is operating in the two many-server heavy-traffic regimes, the quality-driven and the quality-and-efficiency-driven regimes. We have also characterized the transient and stationary distributions of the associated limiting processes. (2) We have studied the reliability and provisioning problems for FJNs with NES operating in random environments, particularly,  establishing functional limit theorems for two-parameter stochastic processes describing the service, queueing and synchronization dynamics in FJNs systems with service interruptions and/or with Markov-modulated arrival processes. The studies have provided insights on the design (resilient network structure and topology) and management to prevent service interruptions, account for demand variability and minimize their degrading effects. (3) We have developed a new method to prove weak convergence of two-parameter processes using the maximal inequalities resulting from the method of chaining. The method not only dramatically simplifies the tightness proofs of convergence of non-Markovian many-server queues with iid service times, but also provides a unified approach for systems with non-iid service times, for example, nonstationary service times and weakly dependent service times. (4) We have proved new maximal inequalities that extend the classical ones in Billingsley (1999), which can be used to prove weak convergence of stochastic processes  and the existence of processes in the space D.

The broad impact of this proposal is profound. The research findings will have a broad impact on the efficiency and quality of care in healthcare, and on the improvement of the society via cloud-based services from data centers, as well as on the broad subject of stochastic modeling and analysis. The research results have been included in the existing graduate courses on service networks and stochastic processes/models.  The research has resulted in young STEM-trained graduates with new mathematical tools that help understand and improve the efficiency and quality of delivered services.
